title: 108_hr2630
content: The Act may be cited as the "Commercial Alien Smuggling Elimination Act of 2003" or the "CASE Act of 2003." It introduces a new class of nonimmigrant aliens. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to include a new clause for nonimmigrant aliens possessing critical reliable information on alien smuggling organizations. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to include a new clause for nonimmigrant aliens possessing critical reliable information on alien smuggling organizations, who are willing to supply such information to a court and whose presence in the US is deemed essential for a criminal investigation or prosecution. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to include provisions for nonimmigrant aliens with critical information on alien smuggling organizations, essential for criminal investigations or prosecutions. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to limit the number of nonimmigrant visas for aliens with critical information on alien smuggling organizations to 400 per fiscal year. Additionally, officials are authorized to take necessary actions to protect the identity of these nonimmigrants and their family members. SEC. 3. Adjustment of status of nonimmigrant to that of person admitted for permanent residence. Section 245(j) of the Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to include new provisions regarding nonimmigrants admitted under section 101(a)(15)(S)(iii) supplying specific information. The Secretary of Homeland Security may adjust the status of an alien and their family members to that of an alien lawfully admitted for permanent residence if the provision of specific information has significantly contributed to a commercial alien smuggling investigation, operation disruption, or individual prosecution. The Secretary of Homeland Security has the authority to adjust the status of a nonimmigrant admitted under a specific section to that of an alien lawfully admitted for permanent residence based on a recommendation from the Secretary of State or the Attorney General. If the identity of the person being adjusted must be protected, the Secretary of Homeland Security, Secretary of State, or Attorney General can make that determination. The official may take necessary lawful action to protect the identity of a person whose status is adjusted under this subsection. SEC. 4. BRINGING IN AND HARBORING CERTAIN ALIENS. Criminal penalties under the Immigration and Nationality Act may be increased by up to 10 years for individuals who bring aliens into the United States in violation of the law, under certain conditions. A rewards program is established in the Department of Homeland Security to assist in eliminating commercial alien smuggling that endangers lives by transporting aliens in groups of 10 or more. The rewards program established by the Department of Homeland Security aims to eliminate commercial alien smuggling that endangers lives by transporting groups of 10 or more aliens. The program is administered by the Secretary of Homeland Security, in consultation with the Attorney General and the Secretary of State, and allows for rewards to be paid to individuals at the discretion of the Secretary. The Secretary of State may offer a reward for information leading to the arrest or conviction of individuals involved in commercial alien smuggling that endangers lives or poses a health risk to people in the United States. The Secretary of State may offer a reward for information leading to the prevention, frustration, or resolution of commercial alien smuggling acts, including dismantling smuggling organizations or identifying key leaders involved in transporting groups of 10 or more aliens. The Secretary of State may offer rewards for preventing or resolving commercial alien smuggling acts involving groups of 10 or more aliens. Appropriations are authorized for implementing this subsection, and government officials are ineligible if involved in such activities. The government officials involved in furnishing information while on duty are not eligible for rewards. The Secretary of Homeland Security, State, or Attorney General can take protective measures for individuals providing information. The Secretary of Homeland Security may authorize rewards up to $100,000, or more if necessary, to combat large-scale alien smuggling operations. The Secretary of Homeland Security may authorize rewards up to $100,000, or more if necessary, to combat large-scale alien smuggling operations. Transportation of aliens in groups of 10 or more must not endanger their lives or pose a life-threatening health risk to people in the United States. Rewards exceeding $50,000 require personal approval by the Secretary of Homeland Security and certification for payment. The Secretary of Homeland Security, in consultation with other relevant departments, will develop an outreach program to educate the public about penalties for bringing in and harboring aliens, as well as the financial rewards available. The Secretary of Homeland Security will develop an outreach program to educate the public about penalties for assisting in the investigation, disruption, or prosecution of a commercial smuggling operation, as well as the financial rewards and incentives available.
